page.title: 19INDUSTRY,CRAY RESERVOIR
page.content: Cray Reservoir dates from the first decade of the twentieth century, when the upper part of Cwm Crai was dammed to form a reservoir to provide water for the Swansea Water Company. The dam is a steep masonry dam with a row of holes through which excess water escapes when the reservoir is full. Although this supply may have been sufficient for the needs of Swansea in 1907, the size of the urban area has increased immensely as also the demand for water. Consequently Cray Reservoir hasd become too small by the nineteen forties so that after the war, Usk Reservoir was also built. By the late sixties this, too, was in- adequate so that the Llyn Brianne scheme was also developed. Nevertheless Cray Reservoir is still part of the overall water supply for the Swansea connurbation.
